tossups.question: In a story by this author, a man gets sexually aroused by his gun and writes to 102 writers saying that he is going to use his six bullets to kill five people, then himself. In another story by this author, a character notes “I have spent my time counterfeiting eternity.” In a story by this author of “Erostratus,” a Belgian doctor assures that “it’s all over quickly” when asked by Tom how long death by firing squad takes; later, false information on the location of Ramon Gris turns out to be true, delaying (*) Pablo Ibbieta’s execution. In a play by this author, a lesbian postal clerk explains her death by gas in a room with Second Empire furnishings. In that play by this author of “The Wall,” the valet only converses with Joseph, who concludes that “hell is other people.” For 10 points, who wrote No Exit?
tossups.answer: Jean-Paul Sartre <WA, Short>

tossups.question: This type of data is the main input to an algorithm that uses Horner’s rule to compute a decimal value denoted by lowercase p. This is the type of data typically stored in a structure called a trie [try]. This type of data can be manipulated using an algorithm that avoids the need to calculate a transition function by using a prefix function. A rolling hash function is calculated for this type of data in the (*) Rabin–Karp algorithm. A linear-time algorithm for data of this type is named for Knuth, Morris, and Pratt. The “grep” command finds instances within them that match regular expressions. You can concatenate or print data of this type, which are often constructed using double quotes. For 10 points, name this data type that represents text.
tossups.answer: strings [prompt on text or patterns] <RY, CompSci>

tossups.question: This house held the lands north of a country where it funded military communities during the so-called “Little War.” This house was able to expand its holdings thanks to the death of a neighboring ruler at the Battle of Ksar el-Kebir. The supremacy of a military formation pioneered by rulers of this house was crushed at the Battle of Rocroi [roh-KWAH]. This house’s rule over one territory was opposed by the Sea Beggars. Its failure to pay (*) tercio units led to the 1576 Sack of Antwerp. The Revolt of the Comuneros took place under the rule of a member of this house, which produced a ruler who launched a disastrous naval invasion of England in 1588. For 10 points, name this royal house that ruled Spain in the 16th and 17th centuries under kings like Philip II.
tossups.answer: House of Habsburg <AF, ContHist>

tossups.question: Sir John Lawrence almost lost one of these items, but recovered it thanks to an honest valet, when he took it from India to give to Queen Victoria. As presented by Adam Smith, the “paradox of value” contrasts the cheapness of water and the expense of these objects. Sir William Crookes named a large one of these objects after William Cullinan. Ahmad Shah Durrani recovered one of these items from the plunder of Nader Shah; that one, placed by Shah Jahan on the (*) Peacock Throne, is the Koh-i-Noor. In an F. Scott Fitzgerald novella, Percy claims that his father has one of these items larger than a hotel. Many of these were taken from the earth at Kimberley by the de Beers company. For 10 points, name these valuable objects, “blood” examples of which proliferate throughout Africa.
tossups.answer: diamonds [prompt on jewels or Crown Jewels] <VC, Other>

tossups.question: Frederic Clements described a theory of this process in plants that he called relay floristics. Joseph Connell and Ralph Slatyer described this process using the facilitation, tolerance, and inhibition models. This phenomenon occurs for animals as a consequence of it happening for plants, according to the habitat accommodation model. This process, which can be autogenic or allogenic, includes the rise of (*) pioneer species and reaches equilibrium at a climax community. The secondary type of this process is in response to natural or manmade destruction of an ecosystem. For 10 points, what term in ecology describes how a biological community evolves over time?
tossups.answer: ecological succession <RY, Biology>

tossups.question: This group’s traditional ideas are philosophically interpreted in the book Quaestiones et Solutiones. An essay about this group argues that “political emancipation” is counterproductive for “human emancipation” and responds to a Bruno Bauer essay of the same title. Perspectives on this group represent a “comprehensive attitude… toward man in general” according to a Jean-Paul Sartre essay. An 1848 essay on the materialist view of history considers the “secular basis” for this group’s (*) religion; that Marx essay is titled for their namesake “Question.” Their influence on music was blasted in an essay by Richard Wagner. For 10 points, name this religious group to whom a “Final Solution” was proposed by Adolf Hitler.
tossups.answer: Jews [or Jewish people] (the first work is by Philo of Alexandria) <WA, PhilO>

tossups.question: When this composer tried to win the Prix de Rome a second time, Hector Berlioz quipped that he “knows everything, but lacks inexperience.” This composer’s Piano Concerto No. 2 opens with a cadenza, moves into a second movement timpani solo, and ends in a tarantella. A 3-minute piece by this composer depicting a bird is often performed as a piece for solo cello. For Pablo de Sarasate, this composer wrote an A minor violin showpiece titled (*) Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso. A tone poem by this composer opens with a harp playing D twelve times to represent the stroke of midnight, and features a xylophone. A suite by this composer contains sections named for “Tortoises” and “The Swan.” For 10 points, name this composer of Danse macabre and The Carnival of the Animals.
tossups.answer: Camille Saint-Saëns <EX, Music>

tossups.question: The first African-American to hold this post was told that his political career “was dead” after the murder of Yankel Rosenbaum. A man in this office accused power providers of “gross negligence” in the leadup to a catastrophic 1977 blackout. A holder of this office clamped down on “squeegee men” with the aid of Bill Bratton. Another holder of this office said that his state’s capital lacked “a good Chinese restaurant” while running for governor against (*) Mario Cuomo. Former holders of this office include David Dinkins and Ed Koch. One of its recent holders was derided by Joe Biden for running for President on the sentence structure, “a verb, a noun, and 9/11.” For 10 points, name this position previously held by Rudy Giuliani and now by Bill de Blasio.
tossups.answer: Mayor of New York City [accept equivalents in place of “New York City,” such as NYC or The Big Apple] <LS, AmHist>

tossups.question: One of these figures names a hadith that describes a time when the masters of black camels dispute with others, and when slaves give birth to their masters. A virgin who visited Idris and then refused food and drink revealed herself to actually be one of these figures. The human-faced horse Buraq was summoned by one of these figures so that a man could perform the Isra and Mi’raj. One of these figures gave the command (*) “Read!” or “Recite!” to a man who had journeyed to the Cave of Hira. The Night of Power took place when one of these figures revealed the first verses of the Quran to Muhammad. For 10 points, name these beings of light that in Islam include Israfil, Mikail, and Jibril, the latter of which is called Gabriel in English.
tossups.answer: angels [or malak; or mala’ikah] <VC, Rel>

tossups.question: This poet asked “What felt those poets but you feel the same?” of a man “beneath the myrtle shade” in a poem whose title implicitly compares Horace’s patron to this poet’s patron, Selina Hastings. This poet wrote “he longed to see America excel” of a dead minister who “leaves the earth for heav’n’s unmeasured height.” This author wrote of “a crown, a mansion, and a throne that shine” in one poem, and opened another with (*) “Hail, happy saint, on thy immortal throne!” A poem by this author of “On the Death of George Whitefield” states “Columbia’s scenes of glorious toils I write” and says “Proceed, great chief, with virtue on thy side / Thy every action let the Goddess guide” to a general. For 10 points, name this early African-American female poet of “To His Excellency General Washington.”
tossups.answer: Phillis Wheatley (the first poem is “Maecenas”) <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: If the ratio of the K value for the “light key” and “heavy key” equals one, then one type of this procedure is impossible. A clevenger apparatus is used to extract essential oils from plants in a type of this procedure. A Perkin triangle is used to conduct this procedure under vacuum. A diagram depicting this procedure has a steplike appearance with one step for each theoretical (*) plate necessary to accomplish it. That is the McCabe–Thiele plot. A jacketed tube that can be filled with water to cool and collect the results of this procedure is called a condenser. This procedure makes use of a column that can be packed with steel wool or Raschig rings as a way to increase area without resorting to the fractional variety of this procedure. For 10 points, name this type of procedure that separates liquid mixtures by boiling them.
tossups.answer: distillation [accept steam distillation or vacuum distillation or column distillation] <JL, Chem>

tossups.question: One method for finding a set of values that are used to describe this property makes use of a Babinet–Soleil compensator and is named for Kent and Lawson. The rotation angle and the ellipticity angle are both multiplied by a factor of two in a set of values that are used to describe this property; those values can be plotted on a Poincaré [pwann-kah-RAY] sphere and are called Stokes (*) parameters. For light that is fully exhibiting this property, Jones calculus is employed instead of Mueller calculus. Light exhibiting this property cannot pass through two filters at orthogonal angles to each other according to Malus’s [mah-LOOSE’s] law, which calculates the intensity of light that exhibits it. For 10 points, identify this property that can come in circular, elliptical and linear forms and describes the electric field oscillation of an electromagnetic wave.
tossups.answer: polarization <SB, Phys>

tossups.question: A song named for this location said that “it’s so dark. / Fido is afraid to bark.” That song appears on a Mel Torme [TOR-may] album titled “Swinging [here],” in which only the song “A Velvet Affair” is not titled for this location. Another song titled for this location featured Nancy Hamilton’s lyrics and chords that were later used by Charlie Parker in Ornithology. Those lyrics asked “Somewhere there’s Heaven; (*) How near? How Far?” A more famous song titled for this location asks to “Fill my heart with song / let me sing forever more.” That song named for this location asks the target to “let me see what spring is like on / a-Jupiter and Mars.” For 10 points, name this location that, “In Other Words,” Frank Sinatra asks you to “Fly me to.”
tossups.answer: the Moon [accept Luna or Earth’s Moon] <JL, OAudArt>

tossups.question: These items and “Conceptual Models” appear in the title of a paper outlining “rational policy,” “organizational process,” and “bureaucratic politics” in foreign policy, written by Graham T. Allison. During a “walk in the woods,” Paul Nitze made an offer concerning these items, which eventually led to the 1987 INF Treaty. The term MANPADS [man-pads] refers to a type of these devices usable by a (*) single person. An agency named for these items operates a facility on Kwajalein Atoll, and developed from Ronald Reagan’s Strategic Defense Initiative. North Korean versions of these weapons, called “Hwasong,” are derived from the Soviet Scud type. For 10 points, name these weapons that can carry nuclear warheads.
tossups.answer: missiles [accept any specific type of missile; accept rockets although they are not the same; prompt to be less specific on nuclear weapons or nukes] <RY, OtherHist>

tossups.question: This book says men marry because “possession is impossible without marriage” but women do since “marriage is impossible without possession” in a chapter where Cainy is asked to leave. In this novel, a man splits a caterpillar in two and cuts a lock of hair in a flashy show of swordplay. At the end of its first chapter, “Vanity” is said to be the flaw of a “handsome maid” who later moves to a nearby town, and flirts with a neighboring 40-year-old farmer in (*) Weatherbury by sending a valentine saying “marry me.” A character in this novel is financially ruined when his inexperienced dog George drives his sheep off a cliff. Sergeant Troy features in this novel, which takes its title from “Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard.” For 10 points, Bathsheba Everdeen appears in what Thomas Hardy novel?
tossups.answer: Far From the Madding Crowd <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: Twelve names of this place’s owner are listed by a figure who describes residents of it named “High,” “Just-As-High,” and “Third.” It is unknown whether a passage describing this place uses the word for “hundred” or “long hundred,” so whether this place has 540 or 640 doors is unclear. An unnamed red bird in the underworld is the counterpart to one who lives at this location, who has a name meaning “golden comb.” Half the people (*) eligible to enter this place instead go to Folkvang, where they won’t be bothered by the rooster Gullinkambi who lives here. This place is the residence of the einherjar [AYN-her-yahr] who feast often and prepare themselves for when they will fight on the fields of Vigrid at Ragnarok. For 10 points, name this place where Valkyries deposit the souls of warriors who died bravely in battle.
tossups.answer: Valhalla [prompt on Asgard until it is read] <VC, Myth>

tossups.question: A woman in this play proclaims that “Man is forgetful, but God remembers” after hearing a doctor complain about how no one will remember the lives he saved in 200 years. A man in this play exclaims that “not every man is capable of being a writer perpetuum immobile” after his mother accuses him of losing his convictions. A servant in this play objects to being called Ilia, saying he prefers a name that suits the marks that cover his face, that of (*) “Waffles.” Yelena repeatedly refuses the advances of the title character of this play, finding herself attracted to Astrov. After hearing Professor Serebryakov’s plan to sell his estate, the title character of this play tries and fails to shoot him twice. For 10 points, name this play by Anton Chekhov about a man named Ivan Voynitsky.
tossups.answer: Uncle Vanya <SB, Drama>

tossups.question: The “reservation” value of this quantity must be known to impose the first of three different degrees of restrictions on it. The product of this quantity and x is generally minimized when finding the optimal point on a Hicksian function. The cost imposed by changing these things on businesses is called “menu cost.” A firm is generally described as a (*) “taker” of this quantity in perfect competition. Deadweight loss can be created by placing a “floor” or a “ceiling” on this quantity, whose [emphasize] rate of change is denoted pi. It is the vertical axis on a standard supply-demand chart. For 10 points, give this quantity that rises during inflation.
tossups.answer: prices [prompt on costs] <WA, SocSci>

tossups.question: A visit from this person resulted in an artist bemoaning to Henri Fantin-Latour that he had to “purify” his house “from cellar to eaves.” The author of The Gentle Art of Making Enemies explained that he was annoyed that a painting of this person was called a “portrait”; that painting contains a floral-patterned curtain on the left, indicating its artist’s japonisme [zhah-poh-NEEZ-muh] inspired style. William Boxall’s lobbying led to the display of a painting of this person at the Royal Academy despite its monochromatic style. After viewing a painting of this person, (*) Thomas Carlyle agreed to sit for a similar portrait, also created by this person’s son, whose works include the Peacock Room. For 10 points, name this American, the subject of an “Arrangement in Grey and Black, No. 1” by her painter son, who created many nocturnes.
tossups.answer: Whistler’s mother [or Anna Whistler; do not accept “James Whistler”; prompt on Whistler] <EX, Painting>

tossups.question: Two iron gates were returned to this city after they were forcibly removed to help fend off a rebellion in one neighborhood. A 1968 flu pandemic named for this city killed approximately one million people worldwide. 1967 leftist riots in this city got foreign administrators in Whitehall to push anti-Communist education here. This site of the Kam Tin rebellion is the only one of the so-called (*) “Four Tigers” that is not a country. It suffered almost 300 deaths during a SARS outbreak in 2003. The destruction of a “walled city” near this territory’s Kai Tak airport led it to be recognized as another’s country’s “Special Administrative Region.” For 10 points, name this city on the Kowloon peninsula that was handed over by Britain to China in 1997.
tossups.answer: Hong Kong [or Hsiang Kang; or Xiang Gang] <SB, WorldHist>

bonuses.leadin: Meteorologist Isaac Cline had argued against building a seawall prior to this disaster, tragically leading to his wife’s death. For 10 points each:
answers: Galveston hurricane of 1900 [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify this 1900 event, the deadliest natural disaster in American history. It destroyed most of a city that is home to the Strand Historic District.

Hundreds of African American victims of a hurricane named after this body of water were buried in unmarked graves in West Palm Beach. That 1928 hurricane was the second deadliest natural disaster in US history.
The 1938 New England Hurricane, which killed nearly 1,000 people, made landfall on this large US island, destroying many homes in The Hamptons and other areas. The first Levittown was built here.

bonuses.leadin: A supercurrent forms during the Josephson effect because this phenomenon occurs between two superconducting cooper pairs at a Josephson junction. For 10 points each:
answers: WKBJ approximation [or Wentzel–Kramers–Brillouin–Jeffreys approximation; accept LG or Liouville–Green method; accept initialisms in any order] <SB/JL, Phys>
parts: Name this classically forbidden process where a particle crosses through a potential energy barrier higher than its own energy.
Tunneling is usually taught when looking at the solutions of this equation for a positive square potential. The time-independent form of this equation is “E psi equals H psi.”

Applying this approximation to the Schrodinger equation can help find the probability that tunneling will occur. In this method, Airy functions are introduced when the potential energy is equal to the total energy.

bonuses.leadin: In March 2017, this country’s Supreme Tribunal of Justice asserted authority over the National Assembly in a move criticized by most Western Hemisphere nations. For 10 points each:
answers: Venezuela [or the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela]
parts: Name this country, whose president since 2013 has been Nicolás Maduro.

Maduro’s government has been strongly criticized by this incumbent governor for the state of Miranda, who co-founded the Justice First party. This man has apparently been banned from participating in politics since early 2017.

In order to fight food shortages, the Maduro government has begun to promote this high-protein, low-cholesterol source of meat. Export of the Flemish Giant variety of this animal to North Korea ended after Kim Jong-il ate all the ones that were sent.

bonuses.leadin: In this book, the character Rashid Khalifa regains his abilities while serving as a speaker for the corrupt politician Snooty Buttoo. For 10 points each:
answers: Haroun and the Sea of Stories
parts: Name this book that is set in a city “so ruinously sad it had forgotten its name.” This novel’s main antagonist, Khattam-Shud, dies crushed by a massive statue of himself that he commissioned.
In a reference to this band, Rushdie’s Haroun and the Sea of Stories features a character called “The Walrus.” A song by this band is described several times in Haruki Murakami’s Norwegian Wood.
A character in the novel named Mudra repeats the names of Franz Kafka and this other author of stories and novels, whose works in the former genre are collected in Evenings on a Farm near Dikanka.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Social Gospel, for 10 points each.
answers: settlement movement [or settlement house movement] <WA, Rel>
parts: Social Gospel writer Charles Weldon popularized this four-word question with the subtitle of his book In His Steps. It may be used to assess one’s behavior in comparison to that of Christ.

Social Gospel believers were considered “post-” this belief, meaning that they thought the Kingdom of God had to be established before the Second Coming. This term generally refers to belief that Jesus will establish the reign of God’s kingdom for a thousand years.

Social Gospel folks contributed to this movement, which called for rich and poor people to live together in interdependent urban communities. It was kicked off by vicar Samuel Augustus Barnett founding Toynbee Hall.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Inger despairs over the fact that her fifth child is born with the same harelip that she has, so she kills the baby. For 10 points each:
answers: Growth of the Soil [or Markens Grode]
parts: Name this novel, one of the first to feature stream-of-consciousness writing, which follows the hard-working Isak as he pioneers the settlement of the Almenning.
A writer with this surname coined the term “stream of consciousness” in the book Principles of Psychology. His brother was a novelist who wrote The Ambassadors.

This novel, which heavily uses stream-of-consciousness writing, consists of seventeen chapters and took its author seventeen years to complete. It opens mid-sentence with the line “riverrun, past Eve and Adam’s.”

bonuses.leadin: A son of Shiva who takes this animal form is named Jambavan and circled Vamana seven times during the churning of the ocean of milk. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these animals. The founder of the first Korean kingdom, Dangun [dahn-goon], is traditionally held to be a son of one.
This indigenous people of Northern Japan carries out the iomante ceremony in which a bear’s blood is drunk. Their deities include Repun Kamuy, the god of the sea, and Kim-un Kamuy, the god of bears.
In Japanese folklore, the onikuma – whose name means “demon-bear” – is a variety of these strange creatures, many of which lack limbs. They include the water-dwelling kappa.

bonuses.leadin: This company produced a film in which a man builds a makeshift bus to reenact his fantasy of meeting a redheaded girl. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American film studio whose output includes Swiss Army Man, Ex Machina, and Barry Jenkins’s film Moonlight, which won 2016’s Best Picture Oscar.

In Swiss Army Man, Daniel Radcliffe repeatedly hums a version of the theme from this earlier film. John Williams composed that theme, which plays in this film as a group of people in a Jeep encounter a brachiosaurus.

This A24 film ends with a long take of a woman seated alone at a diner booth. Yorgos Lanthimos directed this 2015 film about a dystopia in which people are given a last chance to find a spouse before being turned into animals.

bonuses.leadin: Many properties of this set are deducible from the Peano axioms, the first of which states that zero is a member of this set. However zero is occasionally assigned to the whole numbers rather than this set. For 10 points each:
answers: successor function [or succ; prompt on S]
(Julius Wilhelm) Richard Dedekind [accept Dedekind cut] <JL, Math>
parts: Name this set of numbers, symbolized N, whose members are 1, 2, 3, and so on.

The last three of the Peano axioms are used to define properties of this function, which adds one to a number. This operator, and the definition of the first member of the set, are all that is needed to define the natural numbers.

The Peano axioms were later reworked by this mathematician who also developed a method of constructing the reals by making two subsets of the rational numbers where all members of the first are less than those in the second and the first has no greatest member.

bonuses.leadin: Name these Renaissance men, for 10 points each.
parts: This goldsmith, soldier, and poet wrote a best-selling memoir in which he claimed to have fired the shot that killed Charles III, Duke of Bourbon during the 1527 sack of Rome. He was also a sculptor who worked for Francis I.
This champion of a heliocentric, Copernican view of the universe, who spent his last years in house arrest, also developed an improved compass for military engineers.

This man articulated the idea of the Renaissance man by saying “a man can do all things if he will.” This gifted athlete and architect wrote a mathematical treatise on perspective, as well as De re aedificatoria.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about calligraphy, for 10 points each.
parts: The bismillah is often depicted in calligraphy in this language, which is used to decorate the ceilings of mosques.

Rudolph Koch and this father of modern calligraphy pioneered the use of the broad-edged pen. He developed a namesake sans-serif font for the London Underground as well as designing its iconic roundel symbol.
The namesake “miniscule” developed by this European dynasty was used until about 1200 AD by Benedictine and other monks in texts. Its first king built a cathedral at Aachen.

bonuses.leadin: Functional groups with this element and hydrogen are also known as mercaptans because of their strong bonding with mercury. For 10 points each:
answers: colloidal gold [accept gold nanoparticles; prompt on gold; prompt on nanoparticles] <JL, Chem>
parts: Name this element, which comprises thiols along with hydrogen. Its dioxide is a gas that smells like rotten eggs.
This amino acid has a thiol side chain. It is only an essential amino acid in infants and it has a notable selenium derivative like methionine.

Alkane-thiols can be used to form this material, which can be added to fingerprints along with a fluorescent dye to determine, among other things, whether the owner of the fingerprints was a smoker. This material can also be formed with sodium citrate in a method pioneered by Turkevich.

bonuses.leadin: This politician got into a dispute with Edmund Allenby over whether Egypt should pay a fine for the assassination of Lee Stack. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British politician who negotiated the Locarno Pact with Aristide Briand and Gustav Stresemann, for which he won the Nobel Peace Prize.
With Austen Chamberlain, this Conservative was a major advocate for British re-armament during the 1930s. He later served as Prime Minister for most of World War II.
This other Conservative Prime Minister signed the Locarno Pact, and served as Prime Minister three times under three different monarchs in the 1920s and 30s.

bonuses.leadin: This poem is addressed to a woman referred to as “lost discoverer” who “housed the infinite tenderness” of the speaker “like a jar.” For 10 points each:
answers: “The Song of Despair” [or La canción desesperada]
Pablo Neruda [or Neftalí Ricardo Reyes Basoalto]
parts: Name this Spanish poem about a “deserted one” who repeats the refrain “in you everything sank!” while grieving his loss at the “hour of departure.”
This Chilean poet wrote about lost love in the poem “If You Forget Me.” He wrote the collection Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair.

Neruda wasn’t the only heartbroken Chilean poet. This poet leaves with a “forced and sad smile” after urging “generous reader, burn this book” in one of his many antipoems, “I Take Back Everything I’ve Said.”

bonuses.leadin: You’re browsing the DSM-V. Answer some questions about what you find inside, for 10 points each.
answers: borderline personality disorder [accept BPD and emotionally unstable personality disorder] <JM, SocSci>
parts: You discover that this disorder has now been classified as a singular diagnosis compared to its four separate diagnoses in the DSM-IV, two of which were “childhood disintegrative disorder” and “pervasive developmental disorder.
You see that this concept’s “identity disorder” has been renamed to “dysphoria” and now has distinct criteria for diagnosing children, adolescents, and adults.

You find that your pattern of volatile relationships, impulsive behaviors, and fear of abandonment may be a sign of this Cluster B personality disorder that is now commonly treated with dialectical behavior therapy.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about “Blind Sheikh” Omar Abdel-Rahman, for 10 points each.
answers: World Trade Center [prompt on New York City or NYC]
AQAP [or al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula; prompt on al-Qaeda] <EX, WorldHist>
parts: Abdel-Rahman commanded the sect whose member Khalid Islambouli assassinated this Egyptian leader, who negotiated the Camp David Accords.
Abdel-Rahman was finally caught planning a “Landmarks bombing” campaign in 1995 as a follow-up to an earlier truck attack at this location, which was also bombed by Ramzi Yousef in 1993.
Qasim al Raymi, a member of this organization, eulogized Abdel-Rahman after his death in prison. Members of this organization carried out the USS Cole bombing.

bonuses.leadin: Mechanical versions of these structures come in “caged ball,” “tilted disc,” and “bileaflet” types, while bioprosthetic ones are taken from cows or pigs. For 10 points each:
answers: endoplasmic reticulum [or ER; accept rough endoplasmic reticulum or rER; accept smooth endoplasmic reticulum or sER] <RY, Biology>
parts: What four structures allow blood to exit the atria and the ventricles of the heart?

Much of the world’s valve disease is due to rheumatic fever, a disease caused by the pyogenes species of this bacterial genus. It causes scarlet fever, as well as a namesake type of pharyngitis, or throat infection.
Artificial valves often require blood thinners like warfarin, which inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, an enzyme spanning this structure. It houses the chaperone proteins GRP78 and calnexin.

bonuses.leadin: A character in this novel visits Sally Tomato at Sing Sing prison every week and becomes embroiled in his drug ring. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novella about the socialite Holly Golightly, who lives under the apartment of her neighbor, the narrator.
Breakfast at Tiffany’s was penned by this childhood friend of Harper Lee, who detailed the murder of the Clutter family in his nonfiction novel In Cold Blood.

In the book, Holly decides to leave for this country after learning that her lover José has abandoned her to go back to this home country of his. Angel Clare moves to this country after learning of Tess’s “impurity” in Tess of the D’Urbervilles.

bonuses.leadin: Communitarian scholars such as Michael Sandel attack the “atomizing” nature of this man’s philosophy. For 10 points each:
answers: anarchy [or anarchism; accept Anarchy, State, and Utopia] <EX, PhilO>
parts: Name this philosopher of ethics, who revisited several of his definitions in the book Political Liberalism.

Rawls distinguished between complete compliance to his idea of “justice as fairness” and partial compliance in the real world as examples of these two competing ways of doing political philosophy. Name both.
Robert Nozick, a critic of Rawls’s work, advocated a libertarian response in his book titled after this concept, state, and utopia. Pierre-Joseph Proudhon advocated this stateless form of existence.

bonuses.leadin: This composer quoted the “minor seventh leap and half step down” theme from the slow movement of Beethoven’s “Emperor” Concerto to open his song “There’s a Place for Us.” For 10 points each:
answers: Charles Ives (That series of lectures is The Unanswered Question)
parts: Name this conductor, composer, and educator who wrote the legendary Broadway flop 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue and symphonies named Jeremiah and the Age of Anxiety.

A televised series of Bernstein lectures was titled for a composition by this other American composer. Bernstein conducted the world premiere of this composer’s Symphony No. 2 three years before this man died in 1954.
Bernstein’s 1989 Berlin concert replaced this word with “freedom” in a line from Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9. It titles an “Ode” adapted by Beethoven from a Schiller poem.
